Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s excited texts lighting up the screen. She’d just gotten her dream job, and our family group chat was buzzing with plans for a surprise dinner. I wanted to be there, to celebrate her, to be the supportive sister she deserved. But at the same time, my headset buzzed with the voice of Mr. Harris, a long-time customer, his tone sharp and skeptical. “How do I know this isn’t just another scam?” he demanded, his frustration palpable. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “Never let a customer feel unheard. Handle every objection, no matter how tough.” My sister’s messages kept popping up, her joy so clear, and I felt the weight of missing out. I was torn—my family expected me to show up, to cheer and laugh and make memories, but my job demanded my full attention, especially with a customer on the edge. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on Mr. Harris’s questions, but my mind kept drifting to my sister’s celebration, the two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
